Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: They must follow strict procedures for a large cash deposit at the end of a busy shift to comply with corporate auditing rules.
Story: I glance at the clock as I count the bills for the end-of-day deposit, my hands moving automatically through the motions I’ve done a hundred times. The store is quiet now, but my mind is racing. My phone buzzes with a message from my partner: “Rough day, just want to talk when you’re home.” I can almost hear the tiredness in their words, the way they need me to listen, to be present, to offer comfort. But the deposit must be perfect—every bill, every slip, every signature. The manager made it clear: no shortcuts, no mistakes, or the audit could come down hard on all of us. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. I want to drop everything and call, to be the supportive spouse they expect, but the cash in front of me demands my full attention. My heart aches with guilt as I wrestle with the urge to rush through the deposit, knowing I can’t afford an error, but also knowing someone I love is waiting for me to be there.
